A voter wrote to me and asked what can be done about it should Reform get into power at County Hall, which is a valid and interesting question to explore.
While it’s easy to point out wastes of money, it’s not always easy to stop them and the reasons behind spending are not always apparent.
My answer is below:
My Response
Good Morning X,
Interesting question. As I’m not sure of your background knowledge on the subject and it’s a wide-ranging topic, I’ve answered as comprehensively as possible with brevity.
Lancashire County Council are obliged by the Equality Act 2010 and Local Government Association (LGA) guidance to make their services ‘accessible’ to all. The legal interpretation of the Act and guidance means that, in the absence of the Government changing the law and the LGA guidance changing accordingly (which is only likely with a Reform government), translation services are required in some form, for the foreseeable.
What form those services take, and getting value for money for the taxpayer within the legal parameters (until there is a change of government), is another matter. However as this tender has already been awarded, there’s likely to be severance fees that would make it costly to get out of, and it may have restrictions on reducing the amount the tender is used.
In terms of interim solutions for when the tender expires and before a Reform Gov that can be implemented at County Hall, I would strongly argue that existing free translation technology is adequate for translating most languages in a manner that is legally compliant, particularly the primary languages of most of the nations which most refugees, and those seeking asylum, statistically originate from. Paid software is better, while typically being notably cheaper than the contract value.
Other alternative solutions exist, like utilising language learning models and AI for bespoke solutions, advertising for voluntary translators, directly employing translators for less cost, creating specific form-based solutions in each commonly used language for common tasks etc.
Without fully reviewing the tender documents, such as the RFQ’s and bids etc., and without being at County Hall to best assess the situations which translators are used in, it’s hard to drill into the details and suggest specific remedies for each cost-incurring situation and classify them to create a workable policy to reduce cost, and of course it’d have to be cleared with the Council’s legal team, so it’s not something I can easily do from the outside.
When I worked at LCC it was typical that expensive translators would be used as a first option, without attempting to use technology, and that tender exercises would often be poorly considered in a general sense before being started, leading to much waste.
In the detail provided in the Gov.uk link below, there are situations in which technology-based translation solutions would be appropriate and more efficient, such as document translation.
According to the link, the contract has been awarded to DA Languages Ltd, of Manchester (who are presumably actually ‘D A Languages Ltd’, as no DA Languages Ltd exists), whose accounts show £45m+ turnover with £18m+ profit, so it’s reasonable to conclude that perhaps the Council could achieve better value by utilising technology, employing translators directly, or seeking a different kind of contract and partnership with the private sector at better value.
Strangely the link also lists the ‘reason for not providing organisation identifier’ as them being a sole trader, despite apparently being a private limited company, so something else that needs checking.
I look forward to exploring this further at County Hall and consulting their legal and other teams on how to reduce the costs and putting better ways of working in place for after this contract ends may be most efficient, which seems to reflect the views of the majority of the public on this subject.
I have the will to eliminate LCC deficit by taking an approach of ‘leaving no stone unturned’ on every tender, this one is a drop in the ocean.
If you have any ideas, suggestions, or further questions, then I’m all ears. Often these conversations are easier to have on the phone, or in person, so happy to do either if you wish.
Footnote
I think this accurately summarises why it’s imperative to have eager minds at LCC who wish to proactively look into these things. We pay enough money in tax to get better services, it is wasted.
The Reform County Councillor Candidates I’ve spoken with, in Burnley and beyond, all have an active interest to treat taxpayers money like it’s their own and clean up the mess of years of Tory and Labour mismanagement. But we can only do it with your help and voters.

It’s been announced that the former Conservative leader of Lancashire County Council, Geoff Driver, will finally stand trial in April 2027.

How Many Asylum Seekers Are In Lancashire?
According to 2021 Census data, Lancashire is home to 37,277 ‘resettlers’, people who have come here as refugees or asylum seekers.
According to Lancashire County Council, as of 2023 there were also an additional 6,000 asylum seekers & refugees in Lancashire requiring ‘active support’ through a Government migration scheme.
LCC said this figure has increased by 200% since 2021. A 200% increase from 2021 to 2023 (6,000) means the 2021 figure was 2,000.
LCC also said forecasting predicted the number will continue to grow. A continued 200% increase from the 2023 figure to 2025 means that the present figure would be around 18,000.
If, as LCC’s figures suggest, since 2021, there have been an additional 2,000 (2021) + 6,000 (2023) + 18,000 (2025 estimate) asylum seekers, this equals 26,000, so we’ll use this as an estimated figure.

What Do County Councillors Do?
County Councillors are responsible for setting policies and making decisions for the whole of Lancashire, for everything Lancashire County Council presides over.
They decide matters relating to:
- Education (schools, special educational needs etc.)
- Transport (e.g. roads, potholes, major projects)
- Social care (e.g. services for children, the elderly and the vulnerable)
- Libraries and cultural services (e.g. whether your local library stays open)
- Public health (e.g. sexual health services)
- Waste disposal (e.g. where rubbish from tips goes and who moves it)
- Strategic planning (e.g. major infrastructure projects)
They have meetings at County Hall, in Preston, where such things are decided at both Full Council meetings and on different Committees.
So it’s a County Councillor’s job to represent their local area and its people in meetings at County Hall, as well as helping people in the area to access the Council’s services, such as reporting potholes in need of repair, and help them with issues.
